Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was one of the strangest trials 
in Dutch history. The defendant in this 1947 case 
was an art forger who had counterfeited millions of dollars 
worth of paintings. But he wasn’t arguing his innocence— in fact, his life depended on proving 
that he had committed the fraud. Like many art forgers, 
Han van Meegeren was an artist whose original works had failed 
to bring him renown. Embittered towards the art world, van Meegeren set out to make fools 
of his detractors. He learned all he could 
about the Old Masters— their biographies, their techniques, 
and their materials. The artist he chose for his deception 
was 17th century Baroque painter Johannes Vermeer— an ambitious decision given Vermeer 
was famed for his carefully executed and technically brilliant domestic scenes. Working in secret for six years, 
the forger perfected his art, copying numerous works as practice. He mixed his own paints 
after researching the raw materials and pigments available in Vermeer’s time. He bought 17th century canvases, 
created his own brushes, and aged the works 
by applying synthetic resin and baking them to dry 
and crack the paint. A forensic test could have detected 
the synthetic resin. But at the time, such tests 
were neither advanced nor widespread, and even today verification 
of a painting’s authenticity relies on the assessment 
of art specialists. So it’s a matter of their subjective 
judgment— as well as their reputation. And this is where van Meegeren 
truly outwitted the art world. From his research, he knew historians 
believed Vermeer had an early period of religious painting influenced 
by the Italian painter Caravaggio. The leading authority on Vermeer, 
Abraham Bredius, was a huge proponent of this theory, 
though none of these works had surfaced. So van Meegeren decided to make one. He called it "The Supper at Emmaus." Bredius declared van Meegeren’s fake 
the masterpiece of Vermeer’s oeuvre. Van Meegeren’s forgery was not totally 
up to Vermeer’s technical standards, but these inconsistencies 
could be made to fit the narrative: this was an early work, produced before 
the artist had come into his own. With the stamp of approval 
from the art world, the fake was sold in 1937 
for the equivalent of over $4 million in today’s money. The success prompted van Meegeren 
to forge and sell more works through various art dealers. As unbelievable as it may sound, the art world continued to believe 
in their authenticity. When the Nazis occupied Holland 
during the Second World War, Hermann Göring, 
one of Hitler’s top generals, sought to add a Vermeer 
to his collection of artwork looted from all over Europe. Van Meegeren obliged, selling him 
an alleged early Vermeer painting titled "Christ with the Adulteress." As the tide of the war turned, 
so did van Meegeren’s luck. Following the Allied victory, he was 
arrested for delivering a priceless piece of Dutch heritage to the Nazis— 
an act of treasonous collaboration punishable by death. To prove the painting 
wasn’t a national treasure, he explained step-by-step 
how he had forged it. But he faced an unexpected obstacle— 
the very expert who had enabled his scam. Moved to protect his reputation, Bredius 
defended the painting’s authenticity. With few options left, van Meegeren 
set to work on a "new" Vermeer. When he presented the fake to the court, 
they finally believed him. He was acquitted for collaborating 
with the Nazis— and sentenced to a year imprisonment 
for fraud. Though there’s evidence that van Meegeren 
did, in fact, collaborate with the Nazis, he managed to convince the public 
that he had tricked Göring on purpose, transforming his image into that 
of a folk hero who had swindled the Nazis. Thanks to this newfound notoriety, his works became valuable 
in their own right— so much so that they were later forged 
in turn by his own son. The same canvases went from 
revered classics to despised forgeries to works of art respected for the skill 
and notoriety of the forger.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which Nazi leader did van Meegeren trick with his forgeries?
Options: A. Adolf Hitler, B. Heinrich Himmler, C. Alfred Rosenberg, D. Hermann Goring
Correct Option: D

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was one of the strangest trials 
in Dutch history. The defendant in this 1947 case 
was an art forger who had counterfeited millions of dollars 
worth of paintings. But he wasn’t arguing his innocence— in fact, his life depended on proving 
that he had committed the fraud. Like many art forgers, 
Han van Meegeren was an artist whose original works had failed 
to bring him renown. Embittered towards the art world, van Meegeren set out to make fools 
of his detractors. He learned all he could 
about the Old Masters— their biographies, their techniques, 
and their materials. The artist he chose for his deception 
was 17th century Baroque painter Johannes Vermeer— an ambitious decision given Vermeer 
was famed for his carefully executed and technically brilliant domestic scenes. Working in secret for six years, 
the forger perfected his art, copying numerous works as practice. He mixed his own paints 
after researching the raw materials and pigments available in Vermeer’s time. He bought 17th century canvases, 
created his own brushes, and aged the works 
by applying synthetic resin and baking them to dry 
and crack the paint. A forensic test could have detected 
the synthetic resin. But at the time, such tests 
were neither advanced nor widespread, and even today verification 
of a painting’s authenticity relies on the assessment 
of art specialists. So it’s a matter of their subjective 
judgment— as well as their reputation. And this is where van Meegeren 
truly outwitted the art world. From his research, he knew historians 
believed Vermeer had an early period of religious painting influenced 
by the Italian painter Caravaggio. The leading authority on Vermeer, 
Abraham Bredius, was a huge proponent of this theory, 
though none of these works had surfaced. So van Meegeren decided to make one. He called it "The Supper at Emmaus." Bredius declared van Meegeren’s fake 
the masterpiece of Vermeer’s oeuvre. Van Meegeren’s forgery was not totally 
up to Vermeer’s technical standards, but these inconsistencies 
could be made to fit the narrative: this was an early work, produced before 
the artist had come into his own. With the stamp of approval 
from the art world, the fake was sold in 1937 
for the equivalent of over $4 million in today’s money. The success prompted van Meegeren 
to forge and sell more works through various art dealers. As unbelievable as it may sound, the art world continued to believe 
in their authenticity. When the Nazis occupied Holland 
during the Second World War, Hermann Göring, 
one of Hitler’s top generals, sought to add a Vermeer 
to his collection of artwork looted from all over Europe. Van Meegeren obliged, selling him 
an alleged early Vermeer painting titled "Christ with the Adulteress." As the tide of the war turned, 
so did van Meegeren’s luck. Following the Allied victory, he was 
arrested for delivering a priceless piece of Dutch heritage to the Nazis— 
an act of treasonous collaboration punishable by death. To prove the painting 
wasn’t a national treasure, he explained step-by-step 
how he had forged it. But he faced an unexpected obstacle— 
the very expert who had enabled his scam. Moved to protect his reputation, Bredius 
defended the painting’s authenticity. With few options left, van Meegeren 
set to work on a "new" Vermeer. When he presented the fake to the court, 
they finally believed him. He was acquitted for collaborating 
with the Nazis— and sentenced to a year imprisonment 
for fraud. Though there’s evidence that van Meegeren 
did, in fact, collaborate with the Nazis, he managed to convince the public 
that he had tricked Göring on purpose, transforming his image into that 
of a folk hero who had swindled the Nazis. Thanks to this newfound notoriety, his works became valuable 
in their own right— so much so that they were later forged 
in turn by his own son. The same canvases went from 
revered classics to despised forgeries to works of art respected for the skill 
and notoriety of the forger.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How did van Meegeren set a trap for Vermeer expert Abraham Bredius?
Options: A. He painted in a style that fulfilled Bredius’ unsubstantiated theory about Vermeer, B. He made an exact copy of a Vermeer that Bredius had authenticated, C. He created what appeared to be a famous lost Vermeer about which Bredius had written, D. He included a portrait of Bredius’ ancestor into the purported Vermeer painting
Correct Option: A

Question 3: Which 17th-century Baroque painter's works were chosen by van Meegeren for his deception? Options: A. Caravaggio, B. Rembrandt, C. Rubens, D. Johannes Vermeer Correct Option: D

Question 5: Why did van Meegeren sell the painting "Christ with the Adulteress" to Hermann Göring? Options: A. To fund his art education, B. To gain recognition as an artist, C. To collaborate with the Nazis, D. To make a quick profit Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of van Meegeren's trial for collaborating with the Nazis? Options: A. He was sentenced to life imprisonment, B. He was acquitted for collaborating with the Nazis and sentenced to a year imprisonment for fraud, C. He was sentenced to death, D. He was released on bail Correct Option: B
Question 7: Who defended the authenticity of the painting "Christ with the Adulteress" during van Meegeren's trial? Options: A. The court, B. Hermann Göring, C. Abraham Bredius, D. Han van Meegeren Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the consequence of van Meegeren's newfound notoriety after his trial? Options: A. His works became worthless, B. His reputation as an artist was ruined, C. His works became valuable in their own right, D. He was banned from the art world Correct Option: C
Question 9: Who later forged van Meegeren's works? Options: A. His friend, B. His brother, C. His art dealer, D. His son Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the significance of van Meegeren's story in the context of art history? Options: A. It highlights the importance of authenticity in art, B. It showcases the skill and notoriety of the forger, C. It demonstrates the power of art to deceive and manipulate, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was one of the strangest trials 
in Dutch history. The defendant in this 1947 case 
was an art forger who had counterfeited millions of dollars 
worth of paintings. But he wasn’t arguing his innocence— in fact, his life depended on proving 
that he had committed the fraud. Like many art forgers, 
Han van Meegeren was an artist whose original works had failed 
to bring him renown. Embittered towards the art world, van Meegeren set out to make fools 
of his detractors. He learned all he could 
about the Old Masters— their biographies, their techniques, 
and their materials. The artist he chose for his deception 
was 17th century Baroque painter Johannes Vermeer— an ambitious decision given Vermeer 
was famed for his carefully executed and technically brilliant domestic scenes. Working in secret for six years, 
the forger perfected his art, copying numerous works as practice. He mixed his own paints 
after researching the raw materials and pigments available in Vermeer’s time. He bought 17th century canvases, 
created his own brushes, and aged the works 
by applying synthetic resin and baking them to dry 
and crack the paint. A forensic test could have detected 
the synthetic resin. But at the time, such tests 
were neither advanced nor widespread, and even today verification 
of a painting’s authenticity relies on the assessment 
of art specialists. So it’s a matter of their subjective 
judgment— as well as their reputation. And this is where van Meegeren 
truly outwitted the art world. From his research, he knew historians 
believed Vermeer had an early period of religious painting influenced 
by the Italian painter Caravaggio. The leading authority on Vermeer, 
Abraham Bredius, was a huge proponent of this theory, 
though none of these works had surfaced. So van Meegeren decided to make one. He called it "The Supper at Emmaus." Bredius declared van Meegeren’s fake 
the masterpiece of Vermeer’s oeuvre. Van Meegeren’s forgery was not totally 
up to Vermeer’s technical standards, but these inconsistencies 
could be made to fit the narrative: this was an early work, produced before 
the artist had come into his own. With the stamp of approval 
from the art world, the fake was sold in 1937 
for the equivalent of over $4 million in today’s money. The success prompted van Meegeren 
to forge and sell more works through various art dealers. As unbelievable as it may sound, the art world continued to believe 
in their authenticity. When the Nazis occupied Holland 
during the Second World War, Hermann Göring, 
one of Hitler’s top generals, sought to add a Vermeer 
to his collection of artwork looted from all over Europe. Van Meegeren obliged, selling him 
an alleged early Vermeer painting titled "Christ with the Adulteress." As the tide of the war turned, 
so did van Meegeren’s luck. Following the Allied victory, he was 
arrested for delivering a priceless piece of Dutch heritage to the Nazis— 
an act of treasonous collaboration punishable by death. To prove the painting 
wasn’t a national treasure, he explained step-by-step 
how he had forged it. But he faced an unexpected obstacle— 
the very expert who had enabled his scam. Moved to protect his reputation, Bredius 
defended the painting’s authenticity. With few options left, van Meegeren 
set to work on a "new" Vermeer. When he presented the fake to the court, 
they finally believed him. He was acquitted for collaborating 
with the Nazis— and sentenced to a year imprisonment 
for fraud. Though there’s evidence that van Meegeren 
did, in fact, collaborate with the Nazis, he managed to convince the public 
that he had tricked Göring on purpose, transforming his image into that 
of a folk hero who had swindled the Nazis. Thanks to this newfound notoriety, his works became valuable 
in their own right— so much so that they were later forged 
in turn by his own son. The same canvases went from 
revered classics to despised forgeries to works of art respected for the skill 
and notoriety of the forger.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do most art forgers first turn to forgery?
Options: A. They want to make money and see this as the best way to do so while still making art, B. They feel unfulfilled by their original creations and rejected by the art world, so seek revenge, C. They are looking to become famous so are eager to be caught, after a successful fraud or two, D. They are testing themselves to see if they can match the skill level of the greats
Correct Option: B

Question 5: Why did van Meegeren sell the painting "Christ with the Adulteress" to Hermann Göring? Options: A. To fund his art education, B. To gain recognition as an artist, C. To collaborate with the Nazis, D. To make a quick profit Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of van Meegeren's trial for collaborating with the Nazis? Options: A. He was sentenced to life imprisonment, B. He was acquitted for collaborating with the Nazis and sentenced to a year imprisonment for fraud, C. He was sentenced to death, D. He was released on bail Correct Option: B
Question 7: Who defended the authenticity of the painting "Christ with the Adulteress" during van Meegeren's trial? Options: A. The court, B. Hermann Göring, C. Abraham Bredius, D. Han van Meegeren Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the consequence of van Meegeren's newfound notoriety after his trial? Options: A. His works became worthless, B. His reputation as an artist was ruined, C. His works became valuable in their own right, D. He was banned from the art world Correct Option: C
Question 9: Who later forged van Meegeren's works? Options: A. His friend, B. His brother, C. His art dealer, D. His son Correct Option: D

It showcases the skill and notoriety of the forger, C. It demonstrates the power of art to deceive and manipulate, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

was an art forger who had counterfeited millions of dollars

that he had committed the fraud. Like many art forgers,

to bring him renown. Embittered towards the art world, van Meegeren set out to make fools 
of his detractors. He learned all he could 
about the Old Masters— their biographies, their techniques, 
and their materials. The artist he chose for his deception 
was 17th century Baroque painter Johannes Vermeer— an ambitious decision given Vermeer 
was famed for his carefully executed and technically brilliant domestic scenes. Working in secret for six years, 
the forger perfected his art, copying numerous works as practice. He mixed his own paints 
after researching the raw materials and pigments available in Vermeer’s time. He bought 17th century canvases, 
created his own brushes, and aged the works 
by applying synthetic resin and baking them to dry 
and crack the paint. A forensic test could have detected

an act of treasonous collaboration punishable by death. To prove the painting

in turn by his own son. The same canvases went from 
revered classics to despised forgeries to works of art respected for the skill 
and notoriety of the forger.

Sleep affects the release of neurotransmitters to a great extent Correct Option: D

Question 7: According to research, what is a consequence of sleep deprivation on the brain? Options: A. Increased gray matter, B. Decreased gray matter, C. No change in gray matter, D. Gray matter is relocated to other areas of the brain Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is a result of sleep deprivation? Options: A. Improved mood and reduced symptoms of depression, B. Decreased irritability and mood swings, C. Improved problem-solving abilities and creativity, D. Decreased attention and memory Correct Option: D
Question 9: To what extent does sleep affect the release of neurotransmitters? Options: A. Sleep has no effect on neurotransmitter release, B. Sleep affects the release of neurotransmitters to a small extent, C. Sleep affects the release of neurotransmitters to a moderate extent, D. Sleep affects the release of neurotransmitters to a great extent Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the relationship between sleep and motivation? Options: A. Sleep improves motivation, B. Sleep has no effect on motivation, C. Sleep worsens motivation, D. Sleep affects the release of neurotransmitters, which play a crucial role in motivation Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[ INTRO ] Squeaks and I are celebrating today. Because guess what? It’s almost National Coloring Day! [Squeaks cheers] National Coloring Day is just what it sounds
like: a day to color and have fun. And that’s exactly what we’re going to
do … with a special project. We’re going to make some invisible ink! That means the ink will disappear, and then
you can color over it to reveal a secret message. All you’ll need is baking soda, water, purple
grape juice, two cups, a cotton swab like a Q-tip, and either a paint brush or a cotton ball. Oh, and a piece of white paper to write on,
and a grown-up, of course! The first thing we’ll do is mix a quarter
of a cup of baking soda and a quarter of a cup of water. The measurements don’t need to be exact
— we’re just trying to make sure we have about
the same amount of each. This baking soda-water mixture will be our
ink! [Squeaks is surprised by how simple it is] Yep, that’s all there is to it! Let’s write something on this paper here. Hmmm … let me think of a secret message
for you, Squeaks … OK! Now all we have to do is wait for it to dry,
and the message will be hidden! It looks like the ink is dry, so the secret
message is ready to be revealed! The question is, are you ready, Squeaks? Let’s do it, then! This is what the grape juice is for. We’ll dip the brush into the grape juice,
and paint over the message. Check it out! Science is awesome That was the message! There are lots of ways to make invisible ink
at home, but this is one of the easiest — and, I think, the coolest! Because we’re doing the same thing lots
of scientists do in their labs every day! No, they’re not writing secret messages. But they do mix things together to learn more
about them, like we just did! The baking soda we used to make the invisible
ink is really a type of chemical called a base. And when we added the grape juice to the base
on the paper, they reacted to each other! That means they changed. When it touched the baking soda, a chemical
in the grape juice changed to become darker. That’s why the parts of the paper where
the message was got darker, and we were able to read it! Now, baking soda is a safe chemical, so we
can cook with it and use it for experiments at home, but scientists use it in their labs
sometimes, too. Actually, scientists use all kinds of bases
in their labs, and sometimes they need to be able to test
if a chemical is a base. To do that, they combine the chemical with
something called an indicator. That’s another chemical that scientists
know will change color if it mixes with a base. And guess what? One of the ingredients in grape juice works
as an indicator! It’s called an anthocyanin, and it becomes
a darker purple color when it touches a base. [Squeaks points out that grape juice is already
purple] That’s true, the grape juice is already
purple! But when it touches a base like baking soda,
it becomes a much darker purple. So that’s the scientific secret to our invisible
ink. And now we can write all the secret messages
to each other we want … as long as we have some grape juice on hand! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and don’t forget to check us out on the
YouTube Kids app. We’ll see you next time, here at the Fort! [ OUTRO ]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How much baking soda and water do you need to complete this experiment?
Options: A. 1/4 cup of water and 1/4 cup of baking soda, B. 1/2 cup of water and 1/2 cup of baking soda, C. It doesn't matter how much you have of each, D. About the same amount of both baking soda and water
Correct Option: D

To create a mixture that will disappear and then reveal a secret message., D. To make a mixture that will change color when exposed to light. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens when the grape juice touches the baking soda on the paper? Options: A. The grape juice becomes lighter in color., B. The baking soda becomes lighter in color., C. A chemical in the grape juice changes to become darker, allowing the secret message to be revealed., D. The grape juice and baking soda mix together to form a new substance. Correct Option: C

Question 5: How do scientists test if a chemical is a base? Options: A. By mixing it with water., B. By mixing it with an indicator., C. By heating it up., D. By cooling it down. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is an indicator? Options: A. A chemical that changes color when it touches an acid., B. A chemical that changes color when it touches a base., C. A chemical that does not change color when it touches either an acid or a base., D. A chemical that is used to make invisible ink. Correct Option: B

Because it is safe and can be used for cooking and experiments., D. Because it is a rare substance that is hard to find. Correct Option: C

The grape juice disappears when it touches a base like baking soda. Correct Option: B

Question 17: What is the purpose of using a Q-tip to apply the grape juice to the paper? Options: A. To mix the baking soda and water., B. To write the secret message on the paper., C. To apply the grape juice to the paper., D. To dry the ink. Correct Option: C
Question 18: What happens to the anthocyanin in grape juice when it reacts with a base like baking soda? Options: A. It becomes lighter in color., B. It becomes a darker purple color., C. It remains the same color., D. It disappears. Correct Option: B
Question 19: Why is it important to use a base like baking soda in the experiment? Options: A. Because it is a highly toxic substance., B. Because it is a highly flammable substance., C. [ INTRO ] Squeaks and I are celebrating today. Because guess what? It’s almost National Coloring Day! [Squeaks cheers] National Coloring Day is just what it sounds
like: a day to color and have fun. And that’s exactly what we’re going to
do … with a special project. We’re going to make some invisible ink! That means the ink will disappear, and then
you can color over it to reveal a secret message. All you’ll need is baking soda, water, purple
grape juice, two cups, a cotton swab like a Q-tip, and either a paint brush or a cotton ball. Oh, and a piece of white paper to write on,
and a grown-up, of course! The first thing we’ll do is mix a quarter
of a cup of baking soda and a quarter of a cup of water. The measurements don’t need to be exact
— we’re just trying to make sure we have about
the same amount of each. This baking soda-water mixture will be our
ink! [Squeaks is surprised by how simple it is] Yep, that’s all there is to it! Let’s write something on this paper here. Hmmm … let me think of a secret message

and the message will be hidden! It looks like the ink is dry, so the secret
message is ready to be revealed! The question is, are you ready, Squeaks? Let’s do it, then! This is what the grape juice is for. We’ll dip the brush into the grape juice,

at home, but this is one of the easiest — and, I think, the coolest! Because we’re doing the same thing lots
of scientists do in their labs every day! No, they’re not writing secret messages. But they do mix things together to learn more
about them, like we just did! The baking soda we used to make the invisible
ink is really a type of chemical called a base. And when we added the grape juice to the base

Because it is a highly basic substance., C. Because it is sensitive to test if a chemical is a base., D. Because it is a pigment that changes color when it reacts with a base. Correct Option: D

Question 18: What happens to the anthocyanin in grape juice when it reacts with a base like baking soda? Options: A. It becomes lighter in color., B. It becomes a darker purple color., C. It remains the same color., D. It disappears. Correct Option: B
Question 19: Why is it important to use a base like baking soda in the experiment? Options: A. Because it is a highly toxic substance., B. Because it is a highly flammable substance., C. Because it is safe and can be used for cooking and experiments., D. Because it is a rare substance that is hard to find. Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
[ INTRO ] Squeaks and I are celebrating today. Because guess what? It’s almost National Coloring Day! [Squeaks cheers] National Coloring Day is just what it sounds
like: a day to color and have fun. And that’s exactly what we’re going to
do … with a special project. We’re going to make some invisible ink! That means the ink will disappear, and then
you can color over it to reveal a secret message. All you’ll need is baking soda, water, purple
grape juice, two cups, a cotton swab like a Q-tip, and either a paint brush or a cotton ball. Oh, and a piece of white paper to write on,
and a grown-up, of course! The first thing we’ll do is mix a quarter
of a cup of baking soda and a quarter of a cup of water. The measurements don’t need to be exact
— we’re just trying to make sure we have about
the same amount of each. This baking soda-water mixture will be our
ink! [Squeaks is surprised by how simple it is] Yep, that’s all there is to it! Let’s write something on this paper here. Hmmm … let me think of a secret message
for you, Squeaks … OK! Now all we have to do is wait for it to dry,
and the message will be hidden! It looks like the ink is dry, so the secret
message is ready to be revealed! The question is, are you ready, Squeaks? Let’s do it, then! This is what the grape juice is for. We’ll dip the brush into the grape juice,
and paint over the message. Check it out! Science is awesome That was the message! There are lots of ways to make invisible ink
at home, but this is one of the easiest — and, I think, the coolest! Because we’re doing the same thing lots
of scientists do in their labs every day! No, they’re not writing secret messages. But they do mix things together to learn more
about them, like we just did! The baking soda we used to make the invisible
ink is really a type of chemical called a base. And when we added the grape juice to the base
on the paper, they reacted to each other! That means they changed. When it touched the baking soda, a chemical
in the grape juice changed to become darker. That’s why the parts of the paper where
the message was got darker, and we were able to read it! Now, baking soda is a safe chemical, so we
can cook with it and use it for experiments at home, but scientists use it in their labs
sometimes, too. Actually, scientists use all kinds of bases
in their labs, and sometimes they need to be able to test
if a chemical is a base. To do that, they combine the chemical with
something called an indicator. That’s another chemical that scientists
know will change color if it mixes with a base. And guess what? One of the ingredients in grape juice works
as an indicator! It’s called an anthocyanin, and it becomes
a darker purple color when it touches a base. [Squeaks points out that grape juice is already
purple] That’s true, the grape juice is already
purple! But when it touches a base like baking soda,
it becomes a much darker purple. So that’s the scientific secret to our invisible
ink. And now we can write all the secret messages
to each other we want … as long as we have some grape juice on hand! Thanks for joining us! If you want to keep learning and having fun
with Squeaks and me, hit the subscribe button, and don’t forget to check us out on the
YouTube Kids app. We’ll see you next time, here at the Fort! [ OUTRO ]

Options: A. It helps scientists complete chemical reactions., B. It helps scientists understand if a chemical they are using is a base., C. It helps scientists write secret messages., D. It helps scientists understand what is a chemical.
Correct Option: B

like: a day to color and have fun. And that’s exactly what we’re going to
do … with a special project. We’re going to make some invisible ink! That means the ink will disappear, and then
you can color over it to reveal a secret message. All you’ll need is baking soda, water, purple
grape juice, two cups, a cotton swab like a Q-tip, and either a paint brush or a cotton ball. Oh, and a piece of white paper to write on,
and a grown-up, of course! The first thing we’ll do is mix a quarter
of a cup of baking soda and a quarter of a cup of water. The measurements don’t need to be exact
— we’re just trying to make sure we have about
the same amount of each. This baking soda-water mixture will be our
ink! [Squeaks is surprised by how simple it is] Yep, that’s all there is to it! Let’s write something on this paper here. Hmmm … let me think of a secret message
for you, Squeaks … OK! Now all we have to do is wait for it to dry,
and the message will be hidden! It looks like the ink is dry, so the secret
message is ready to be revealed! The question is, are you ready, Squeaks? Let’s do it, then! This is what the grape juice is for. We’ll dip the brush into the grape juice,
and paint over the message. Check it out! Science is awesome That was the message! There are lots of ways to make invisible ink
at home, but this is one of the easiest — and, I think, the coolest! Because we’re doing the same thing lots
of scientists do in their labs every day! No, they’re not writing secret messages. But they do mix things together to learn more
about them, like we just did! The baking soda we used to make the invisible
ink is really a type of chemical called a base. And when we added the grape juice to the base
on the paper, they reacted to each other! That means they changed. When it touched the baking soda, a chemical
in the grape juice changed to become darker. That’s why the parts of the paper where
the message was got darker, and we were able to read it! Now, baking soda is a safe chemical, so we
can cook with it and use it for experiments at home, but scientists use it in their labs
sometimes, too. Actually, scientists use all kinds of bases
in their labs, and sometimes they need to be able to test

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Transcript not available

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You find a nestling on the ground. What might have happened that it ended up there?
Options: A. it flew out of the nest, B. It was pushed out of the nest, C. It was knocked out of the nest, D. b and c only, E. all of the above are great answers
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is one of the most significant effects of climate change on the environment? Options: A. Increased air pollution, B. Loss of biodiversity, C. Increased water scarcity, D. Soil degradation Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following is a consequence of climate change on ecosystems? Options: A. Increased species diversity, B. Population declines and extinctions, C. Decreased ecosystem services, D. Increased food production Correct Option: B
Question 3: How do many plant and animal species respond to rising temperatures? Options: A. They adapt and thrive, B. They are forced to migrate to new habitats, C. They become extinct, D. They experience no change Correct Option: C
Question 4: How do invasive species affect native species in the context of climate change? Options: A. They outcompete them for resources and habitat, B. They help to control their populations, C. They do not affect them, D. They become extinct Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is one of the economic impacts of the loss of biodiversity on ecosystems? Options: A. Increased food production, B. Reduced ecosystem services, C. Decreased economic growth, D. Increased air pollution Correct Option: B
Question 6: Which of the following is a social impact of the loss of biodiversity on ecosystems? Options: A. Increased social cohesion, B. Reduced ecosystem services, C. Decreased economic growth, D. Increased food security Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between climate change and the distribution and abundance of invasive species? Options: A. Climate change has no effect on invasive species, B. Climate change leads to a decrease in invasive species, C. Climate change leads to an increase in invasive species, D. Climate change has a neutral effect on invasive species Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is one of the far-reaching consequences of climate change on ecosystems? Options: A. Increased species diversity of species, B. Loss of biodiversity, C. Decreased ecosystem services, D. Increased food production Correct Option: B
Question 9: How do the consequences of climate change on biodiversity impact human societies? Options: A. They have no impact, B. They have significant economic and social impacts, C. They lead to increased food security, D. They lead to decreased economic growth Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the significance of the loss of biodiversity in the context of climate change? Options: A. It has no significance, B. It leads to increased food production, C. It leads to reduced ecosystem services, D. It has no impact on human societies Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
According to legend, 
once every thousand years a host of sea monsters emerges 
from the depths to demand tribute from the floating city of Atlantartica. As the ruler of the city, 
you’d always dismissed the stories… until today, when 7 Leviathan Lords 
rose out of the roiling waters and surrounded your city. Each commands 10 giant kraken, and each kraken 
is accompanied by 12 mermites. Your city’s puny army 
is hopelessly outmatched. You think back to the legends. In the stories, the ruler of the city 
saved his people by feeding the creatures 
a ransom of pearls. The pearls would be split equally 
between the leviathans lords. Each leviathan would then divide its share
into 11 equal piles, keeping one, and giving the other 10 
to their kraken commanders. Each kraken would then divide its share 
into 13 equal piles, keeping one, and distributing the other 
twelve to their mermite minions. If any one of these divisions left 
an unequal pile or leftover pearl, the monsters would pull everyone 
to the bottom of the sea. Such was the fate 
of your fabled sister city. You rush to the ancient treasure room 
and find five chests, each containing a precisely counted number
of pearls prepared by your ancestors 
for exactly this purpose. Each of the chests bears a number 
telling how many pearls it contains. Unfortunately, the symbols they used 
to write digits 1,000 years ago have changed with time, and you don’t know how 
to read the ancient numbers. With hundreds of thousands of pearls 
in each chest, there’s no time to recount. One of these chests will save your city and the rest will lead 
to its certain doom. Which do you choose? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There isn’t enough information to decode
the ancient Atlantartican numeral system. But all hope is not lost, because there’s another piece 
of information those symbols contain: patterns. If we can find a matching pattern 
in arabic numerals, we can still pick the right chest. Let’s take stock of what we know. A quantity of pearls that can appease 
the sea monsters must be divisible by 7, 11, and 13. Rather than trying out numbers 
at random, let’s examine ones that have this property and see if there are any 
patterns that unite them. Being divisible by 7, 11, and 13 means that our number must 
be a multiple of 7, 11, and 13. Those three numbers are all prime, 
so multiplying them together will give us their least 
common multiple: 1001. That’s a useful starting place because we now know that any viable 
offering to the sea monsters must be a multiple of 1001. Let’s try multiplying it by a three digit 
number, just to get a feel for what we might get. If we try 861 times 1001, we get 861,861, and we see something similar 
with other examples. It’s a peculiar pattern. Why would multiplying a three-digit 
number by 1001 end up giving you two copies 
of that number, written one after the other? Breaking down the multiplication 
problem can give us the answer. 1001 times any number x is equal 
to 1000x + x. For example, 725 times 1000 is 725,000, 
and 725 x 1 is 725. So 725 x 1001 will be the sum of 
those two numbers: 725,725. And there’s nothing special about 725. Pick any three-digit number, and your final product will have 
that many thousands, plus one more. Even though you don’t know how 
to read the numbers on the chests, you can read which pattern of digits 
represents a number divisible by 1001. As with many problems, trying concrete
examples can give you an intuition for behavior that may at first look
abstract and mysterious. The monsters accept your ransom 
and swim back down to the depths for another thousand years. With the proper planning, that should give you plenty of time 
to prepare for their inevitable return.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Sardines, B. Pearls, C. Gold, D. Oatmeal
Correct Option: B

Question 3: What did Sigmund Freud propose as a means of addressing people's problems? Options: A. Through medication, B. Through talk therapy, C. Through physical exercise, D. Through meditation Correct Option: B
Question 4: How did Sigmund Freud's work impact the medical establishment? Options: A. It led to the dismissal of many medical professionals, B. It forced them to acknowledge the psychological disorders of patients, C. It resulted in the development of new treatments, D. It led to a greater awareness of psychological disorders Correct Option: B
Question 5: What were some of the consequences of Sigmund Freud's ideas being misapplied? Options: A. Patients were cured of their illnesses, B. New treatments were developed, C. Lives and families were torn apart, D. The medical establishment was improved Correct Option: C
Question 6: According to the transcript, what was Sigmund Freud's view on homosexuality? Options: A. He believed it was a natural part of human development, B. He had no opinion on the matter, C. He viewed it as a developmental glitch, D. He believed it was a sign of mental illness Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did Sigmund Freud's ideas influence modern therapy techniques? Options: A. They resulted in the dismissal of many therapists, B. They sparked a revolution in psychology and society, C. They led to the development of new treatments, D. They had no impact on modern therapy techniques Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the "cognitive unconscious"? Options: A. The idea that people are unaware of their motivations and desires, B. The concept that people's thoughts and feelings are influenced by their environment, C. The fact that people are not aware of everything going on at a given moment, D. The idea that people's behaviors are determined by their genetics Correct Option: C
Question 9: According to the transcript, what prehistorical event did Sigmund Freud believe had an ongoing impact on human psychology? Options: A. The construction of the Great Pyramid, B. The Ice Age, C. The Great Flood, D. The killing of Moses Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the transcript's assessment of Sigmund Freud's impact on modern psychology? Options: A. He has been largely discredited and is no longer relevant, B. He has had a lasting impact on the field of psychology and continues to influence modern therapy techniques, C. He has led to the development of new treatments and therapies, D. He has resulted in the dismissal of many medical professionals Correct Option: B
Question 11: What was Sigmund Freud's view on the impact of therapy? Options: A. He was optimistic about its effectiveness, B. He was pessimistic about its impact, C. He believed therapy was effective, but had limited impact on human behavior, D. He believed therapy had no impact on human behavior Correct Option: B
Question 12: According to the transcript, how did Sigmund Freud present himself? Options: A. As a social theorist, B. As a scientist, C. As a philosopher, D. As a historian Correct Option: B
Question 13: What were some of the limitations of Sigmund Freud's ideas, according to the transcript? Options: A. They were based on outdated scientific ideas, B. They were unfalsifiable, C. They were not supported by empirical evidence, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 14: How did Sigmund Freud's ideas influence the concept of the "unconscious," according to the transcript? Options: A. He popularized the idea of the "cognitive unconscious", B. He believed that people are unaware of everything going on at a given moment, C. He took the idea of the "unconscious" too far and ascribed deep meaning to everything, D. He had no influence on the concept of the "unconscious" Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the transcript's conclusion about Sigmund Freud's legacy? Options: A. He was a flawed thinker whose ideas have been largely discredited, B. He was a pioneering thinker who sparked a revolution in psychology and society, C. He was a scientist who presented his work as scientific, but it was actually pseudoscientific, D. He was a philosopher who had no impact on modern psychology Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
According to legend, 
once every thousand years a host of sea monsters emerges 
from the depths to demand tribute from the floating city of Atlantartica. As the ruler of the city, 
you’d always dismissed the stories… until today, when 7 Leviathan Lords 
rose out of the roiling waters and surrounded your city. Each commands 10 giant kraken, and each kraken 
is accompanied by 12 mermites. Your city’s puny army 
is hopelessly outmatched. You think back to the legends. In the stories, the ruler of the city 
saved his people by feeding the creatures 
a ransom of pearls. The pearls would be split equally 
between the leviathans lords. Each leviathan would then divide its share
into 11 equal piles, keeping one, and giving the other 10 
to their kraken commanders. Each kraken would then divide its share 
into 13 equal piles, keeping one, and distributing the other 
twelve to their mermite minions. If any one of these divisions left 
an unequal pile or leftover pearl, the monsters would pull everyone 
to the bottom of the sea. Such was the fate 
of your fabled sister city. You rush to the ancient treasure room 
and find five chests, each containing a precisely counted number
of pearls prepared by your ancestors 
for exactly this purpose. Each of the chests bears a number 
telling how many pearls it contains. Unfortunately, the symbols they used 
to write digits 1,000 years ago have changed with time, and you don’t know how 
to read the ancient numbers. With hundreds of thousands of pearls 
in each chest, there’s no time to recount. One of these chests will save your city and the rest will lead 
to its certain doom. Which do you choose? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There isn’t enough information to decode
the ancient Atlantartican numeral system. But all hope is not lost, because there’s another piece 
of information those symbols contain: patterns. If we can find a matching pattern 
in arabic numerals, we can still pick the right chest. Let’s take stock of what we know. A quantity of pearls that can appease 
the sea monsters must be divisible by 7, 11, and 13. Rather than trying out numbers 
at random, let’s examine ones that have this property and see if there are any 
patterns that unite them. Being divisible by 7, 11, and 13 means that our number must 
be a multiple of 7, 11, and 13. Those three numbers are all prime, 
so multiplying them together will give us their least 
common multiple: 1001. That’s a useful starting place because we now know that any viable 
offering to the sea monsters must be a multiple of 1001. Let’s try multiplying it by a three digit 
number, just to get a feel for what we might get. If we try 861 times 1001, we get 861,861, and we see something similar 
with other examples. It’s a peculiar pattern. Why would multiplying a three-digit 
number by 1001 end up giving you two copies 
of that number, written one after the other? Breaking down the multiplication 
problem can give us the answer. 1001 times any number x is equal 
to 1000x + x. For example, 725 times 1000 is 725,000, 
and 725 x 1 is 725. So 725 x 1001 will be the sum of 
those two numbers: 725,725. And there’s nothing special about 725. Pick any three-digit number, and your final product will have 
that many thousands, plus one more. Even though you don’t know how 
to read the numbers on the chests, you can read which pattern of digits 
represents a number divisible by 1001. As with many problems, trying concrete
examples can give you an intuition for behavior that may at first look
abstract and mysterious. The monsters accept your ransom 
and swim back down to the depths for another thousand years. With the proper planning, that should give you plenty of time 
to prepare for their inevitable return.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What other numbers does the ransom needed to be divided by?
Options: A. 10 and 11, B. 11 and 13, C. 13 and 17, D. 15 and 20
Correct Option: B

He viewed it as a developmental glitch, D. He believed it was a sign of mental illness Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did Sigmund Freud's ideas influence modern therapy techniques? Options: A. They resulted in the dismissal of many therapists, B. They sparked a revolution in psychology and society, C. They led to the development of new treatments, D. They had no impact on modern therapy techniques Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the "cognitive unconscious"? Options: A. The idea that people are unaware of their motivations and desires, B. The concept that people's thoughts and feelings are influenced by their environment, C. The fact that people are not aware of everything going on at a given moment, D. The idea that people's behaviors are determined by their genetics Correct Option: C
Question 9: According to the transcript, what prehistorical event did Sigmund Freud believe had an ongoing impact on human psychology? Options: A. The construction of the Great Pyramid, B. The Ice Age, C. The Great Flood, D. The killing of Moses Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the transcript's assessment of Sigmund Freud's impact on modern psychology? Options: A. He has been largely discredited and is no longer relevant, B. He has had a lasting impact on the field of psychology and continues to influence modern therapy techniques, C. He has led to the development of new treatments and therapies, D. He has resulted in the dismissal of many medical professionals Correct Option: B
Question 11: What was Sigmund Freud's view on the impact of therapy? Options: A. He was optimistic about its effectiveness, B. He was pessimistic about its impact, C. He believed therapy was effective, but had limited impact on human behavior, D. He believed therapy had no impact on human behavior Correct Option: B
Question 12: According to the transcript, how did Sigmund Freud present himself? Options: A. As a social theorist, B. As a scientist, C. As a philosopher, D. As a historian Correct Option: B
Question 13: What were some of the limitations of Sigmund Freud's ideas, according to the transcript? Options: A. They were based on outdated scientific ideas, B. They were unfalsifiable, C. They were not supported by empirical evidence, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 14: How did Sigmund Freud's ideas influence the concept of the "unconscious," according to the transcript? Options: A. He popularized the idea of the "cognitive unconscious", B. He believed that people are unaware of everything going on at a given moment, C. He took the idea of the "unconscious" too far and ascribed deep meaning to everything, D. He had no influence on the concept of the "unconscious" Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the transcript's conclusion about Sigmund Freud's legacy? Options: A. He was a flawed thinker whose ideas have been largely discredited, B. He was a pioneering thinker who sparked a revolution in psychology and society, C. He was a scientist who presented his work as scientific, but it was actually pseudoscientific, D. He was a philosopher who had no impact on modern psychology Correct Option: B

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
According to legend, 
once every thousand years a host of sea monsters emerges 
from the depths to demand tribute from the floating city of Atlantartica. As the ruler of the city, 
you’d always dismissed the stories… until today, when 7 Leviathan Lords 
rose out of the roiling waters and surrounded your city. Each commands 10 giant kraken, and each kraken 
is accompanied by 12 mermites. Your city’s puny army 
is hopelessly outmatched. You think back to the legends. In the stories, the ruler of the city 
saved his people by feeding the creatures 
a ransom of pearls. The pearls would be split equally 
between the leviathans lords. Each leviathan would then divide its share
into 11 equal piles, keeping one, and giving the other 10 
to their kraken commanders. Each kraken would then divide its share 
into 13 equal piles, keeping one, and distributing the other 
twelve to their mermite minions. If any one of these divisions left 
an unequal pile or leftover pearl, the monsters would pull everyone 
to the bottom of the sea. Such was the fate 
of your fabled sister city. You rush to the ancient treasure room 
and find five chests, each containing a precisely counted number
of pearls prepared by your ancestors 
for exactly this purpose. Each of the chests bears a number 
telling how many pearls it contains. Unfortunately, the symbols they used 
to write digits 1,000 years ago have changed with time, and you don’t know how 
to read the ancient numbers. With hundreds of thousands of pearls 
in each chest, there’s no time to recount. One of these chests will save your city and the rest will lead 
to its certain doom. Which do you choose? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There isn’t enough information to decode
the ancient Atlantartican numeral system. But all hope is not lost, because there’s another piece 
of information those symbols contain: patterns. If we can find a matching pattern 
in arabic numerals, we can still pick the right chest. Let’s take stock of what we know. A quantity of pearls that can appease 
the sea monsters must be divisible by 7, 11, and 13. Rather than trying out numbers 
at random, let’s examine ones that have this property and see if there are any 
patterns that unite them. Being divisible by 7, 11, and 13 means that our number must 
be a multiple of 7, 11, and 13. Those three numbers are all prime, 
so multiplying them together will give us their least 
common multiple: 1001. That’s a useful starting place because we now know that any viable 
offering to the sea monsters must be a multiple of 1001. Let’s try multiplying it by a three digit 
number, just to get a feel for what we might get. If we try 861 times 1001, we get 861,861, and we see something similar 
with other examples. It’s a peculiar pattern. Why would multiplying a three-digit 
number by 1001 end up giving you two copies 
of that number, written one after the other? Breaking down the multiplication 
problem can give us the answer. 1001 times any number x is equal 
to 1000x + x. For example, 725 times 1000 is 725,000, 
and 725 x 1 is 725. So 725 x 1001 will be the sum of 
those two numbers: 725,725. And there’s nothing special about 725. Pick any three-digit number, and your final product will have 
that many thousands, plus one more. Even though you don’t know how 
to read the numbers on the chests, you can read which pattern of digits 
represents a number divisible by 1001. As with many problems, trying concrete
examples can give you an intuition for behavior that may at first look
abstract and mysterious. The monsters accept your ransom 
and swim back down to the depths for another thousand years. With the proper planning, that should give you plenty of time 
to prepare for their inevitable return.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What other condition is there on the number of pearls you must give the sea monsters?
Options: A. There must be at least 10 pearls for each creature., B. The leviathan lords must get at least 10 times as many pearls as any other creature., C. The pearls must be able to be cut into quarters., D. There can be no remainders in after any division.
Correct Option: D

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
According to legend, 
once every thousand years a host of sea monsters emerges 
from the depths to demand tribute from the floating city of Atlantartica. As the ruler of the city, 
you’d always dismissed the stories… until today, when 7 Leviathan Lords 
rose out of the roiling waters and surrounded your city. Each commands 10 giant kraken, and each kraken 
is accompanied by 12 mermites. Your city’s puny army 
is hopelessly outmatched. You think back to the legends. In the stories, the ruler of the city 
saved his people by feeding the creatures 
a ransom of pearls. The pearls would be split equally 
between the leviathans lords. Each leviathan would then divide its share
into 11 equal piles, keeping one, and giving the other 10 
to their kraken commanders. Each kraken would then divide its share 
into 13 equal piles, keeping one, and distributing the other 
twelve to their mermite minions. If any one of these divisions left 
an unequal pile or leftover pearl, the monsters would pull everyone 
to the bottom of the sea. Such was the fate 
of your fabled sister city. You rush to the ancient treasure room 
and find five chests, each containing a precisely counted number
of pearls prepared by your ancestors 
for exactly this purpose. Each of the chests bears a number 
telling how many pearls it contains. Unfortunately, the symbols they used 
to write digits 1,000 years ago have changed with time, and you don’t know how 
to read the ancient numbers. With hundreds of thousands of pearls 
in each chest, there’s no time to recount. One of these chests will save your city and the rest will lead 
to its certain doom. Which do you choose? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 There isn’t enough information to decode
the ancient Atlantartican numeral system. But all hope is not lost, because there’s another piece 
of information those symbols contain: patterns. If we can find a matching pattern 
in arabic numerals, we can still pick the right chest. Let’s take stock of what we know. A quantity of pearls that can appease 
the sea monsters must be divisible by 7, 11, and 13. Rather than trying out numbers 
at random, let’s examine ones that have this property and see if there are any 
patterns that unite them. Being divisible by 7, 11, and 13 means that our number must 
be a multiple of 7, 11, and 13. Those three numbers are all prime, 
so multiplying them together will give us their least 
common multiple: 1001. That’s a useful starting place because we now know that any viable 
offering to the sea monsters must be a multiple of 1001. Let’s try multiplying it by a three digit 
number, just to get a feel for what we might get. If we try 861 times 1001, we get 861,861, and we see something similar 
with other examples. It’s a peculiar pattern. Why would multiplying a three-digit 
number by 1001 end up giving you two copies 
of that number, written one after the other? Breaking down the multiplication 
problem can give us the answer. 1001 times any number x is equal 
to 1000x + x. For example, 725 times 1000 is 725,000, 
and 725 x 1 is 725. So 725 x 1001 will be the sum of 
those two numbers: 725,725. And there’s nothing special about 725. Pick any three-digit number, and your final product will have 
that many thousands, plus one more. Even though you don’t know how 
to read the numbers on the chests, you can read which pattern of digits 
represents a number divisible by 1001. As with many problems, trying concrete
examples can give you an intuition for behavior that may at first look
abstract and mysterious. The monsters accept your ransom 
and swim back down to the depths for another thousand years. With the proper planning, that should give you plenty of time 
to prepare for their inevitable return.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Your city will be dragged into the sea., B. Your city will be conquered and occupied by the monsters., C. The monsters will come back later., D. The monsters will hold the royal family hostage.
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Working in Vienna at the turn 
of the 20th century, he began his career as a neurologist before pioneering the discipline 
of psychoanalysis. He proposed that people are motivated 
by unconscious desires and repressed memories, and their problems can be addressed by making those motivations conscious 
through talk therapy. His influence towers above that of all 
other psychologists in the public eye. But was Sigmund Freud 
right about human nature? And were his methods scientific? Order, order. 
Today on the stand we have… Dad? Ahem, no, your honor. This is Doctor Sigmund Freud, one of the most innovative thinkers
in the history of psychology. An egomaniac who propagated 
pseudoscientific theories. Well, which is it? He tackled issues medicine 
refused to address. Freud’s private practice treated women who suffered from what was called 
hysteria at the time, and their complaints hadn’t been taken
seriously at all. From the women with depression 
he treated initially to World War I veterans with PTSD, Freud’s talking cure worked, and the visibility he gave his patients 
forced the medical establishment to acknowledge their psychological 
disorders were real. He certainly didn’t help all his patients. Freud was convinced
that our behavior is shaped by unconscious urges 
and repressed memories. He invented baseless unconscious 
or irrational drivers behind the behavior of trauma 
survivors— and caused real harm. How’s that? He misrepresented some of his most 
famous case studies, claiming his treatment had cured patients 
when in fact they had gotten worse. Later therapists influenced 
by his theories coaxed their patients into "recovering" supposedly repressed memories 
of childhood abuse that never happened. Lives and families were torn apart. You can’t blame Freud for later
misapplications of his work— that would be projecting. Plenty of his ideas were harmful 
without any misapplication. He viewed homosexuality 
as a developmental glitch. He coined the term penis envy— meaning women are haunted for life
by their lack of penises. Freud was a product of his era. Yes, some of the specifics were flawed, but he created a new space 
for future scientists to explore, investigate, and build upon. Modern therapy techniques
that millions of people rely on came out of the work he started 
with psychoanalysis. And today everyone knows 
there’s an unconscious— that idea was popularized Freud. Psychologists today only believe 
in a “cognitive unconscious,” the fact that you aren’t aware 
of everything going on at a given moment. Freud took this idea way too far, 
ascribing deep meaning to everything. He built his theories on scientific ideas
that were outdated even in his own time, not just by today’s standards— for example, he thought 
individual psychology is derived from the biological inheritance
of events in ancient history. And I mean ancient— 
like the Ice Age or the killing of Moses. Freud and his closest allies actually 
believed these prehistorical traumas had ongoing impacts on human psychology. He thought that the phase 
of cold indifference to sexuality during pubescence was literally 
an echo of the Ice Age. With fantastical beliefs like these,
how can we take him seriously? Any renowned thinker from centuries past has ideas that seem fantastical 
by today’s standards, but we can’t discount 
their influence on this basis. Freud was an innovator 
linking ideas across many fields. His concepts have become everyday terms that shape how we understand and talk 
about our own experiences. The Oedipus complex? Ego and id? 
Defense mechanisms? Death wishes? All Freud. But Freud didn’t present himself as a 
social theorist— he insisted that his work was scientific. Are you saying he… repressed
inconvenient facts? Freud’s theories were unfalsifiable. Wait, so you’re saying he was right? No, his ideas were framed so that 
there’s no way to empirically verify them. Freud didn’t even necessarily believe 
in the psychoanalysis he was peddling. He was pessimistic 
about the impact of therapy. What! I think I need to lie down! Many of Sigmund Freud’s ideas 
don’t hold up to modern science, and his clinical practices don’t meet 
today’s ethical standards. At the same time, he sparked 
a revolution in psychology and society, and created a vocabulary 
for discussing emotion. Freud made his share of mistakes. But is a thinker responsible 
for how subsequent generations put their ideas to use? Do they deserve the blame, 
credit, or redemption when we put history on trial?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Freud’s earliest patients were:
Options: A. Men, B. Women, C. Christians, D. Children, E. Scientists
Correct Option: B

Question 1: What was the initial proposal for spanning the 33 kilometer gap of the English Channel? Options: A. A bridge connecting two artificial islands, B. A submerged tube suspended from floating platforms, C. An underwater passage more than twice the length of any existing tunnel, D. A canal with locks Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the main obstacle to the project's completion in the early years? Options: A. Technical difficulties with the tunnel boring machine, B. Financial constraints due to the high cost of the project, C. Fears of French invasion and strategic concerns, D. Environmental concerns about the impact on the marine ecosystem Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the breakthrough that made the tunnel project more feasible? Options: A. The invention of the tunnel boring machine, B. The discovery of a stable layer of chalk marl below the seabed, C. The development of waterproof boring machines, D. A combination of A and B Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the reason for the delay in the project's completion? Options: A. Technical difficulties with the tunnel boring machine, B. Financial constraints due to the high cost of the project, C. The discovery of fault lines on the French coast, D. The flooding of the tunnel due to undetected fissures Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the solution to the problem of drilling in wet chalk? Options: A. Using regular boring machines, B. Using grout to seal the cracks created in the borer's wake, C. Working ahead of the main borer to reinforce the chalk about to be drilled, D. A combination of B and C Correct Option: D
Question 6: What was the average speed of the boring machines? Options: A. 1.5 meters per hour, B. 2.5 meters per hour, C. 3.5 meters per hour, D. 4.5 meters per hour Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the total length of the tunnels built during the project? Options: A. Over 200 kilometers, B. 150 kilometers, C. 100 kilometers, D. 250 kilometers Correct Option: A
Question 8: How many people were employed during the construction of the tunnel? Options: A. 5,000, B. 10,000, C. Over 13,000, D. 20,000 Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the cost of the project in modern equivalent terms? Options: A. 5 billion pounds, B. 10 billion pounds, C. The modern equivalent of 14 billion pounds, D. 20 billion pounds Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the significance of the Channel Tunnel in terms of its impact on society? Options: A. It was a major economic stimulus for the region, B. It was a major environmental disaster, C. It was a major barrier to human migration, D. It was a symbol of humanity breaking down barriers Correct Option: D
Question 11: Who was the first human to cross the channel by land since the Ice Age? Options: A. A British worker, B. A French worker, C. Graham Fagg, D. A team of workers Correct Option: C
Question 12: When did the Channel Tunnel open for full public service? Options: A. May 6, 1994, B. 16 months after the opening ceremony, C. 2 years after the construction started, D. 5 years after the construction started Correct Option: B
Question 13: How many passengers does the Channel Tunnel transport per year? Options: A. 10 million, B. 15 million, C. 20 million, D. 25 million Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the approximate travel time through the Channel Tunnel? Options: A. 45 minutes, B. 50 minutes, C. 35 minutes, D. 40 minutes Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Working in Vienna at the turn 
of the 20th century, he began his career as a neurologist before pioneering the discipline 
of psychoanalysis. He proposed that people are motivated 
by unconscious desires and repressed memories, and their problems can be addressed by making those motivations conscious 
through talk therapy. His influence towers above that of all 
other psychologists in the public eye. But was Sigmund Freud 
right about human nature? And were his methods scientific? Order, order. 
Today on the stand we have… Dad? Ahem, no, your honor. This is Doctor Sigmund Freud, one of the most innovative thinkers
in the history of psychology. An egomaniac who propagated 
pseudoscientific theories. Well, which is it? He tackled issues medicine 
refused to address. Freud’s private practice treated women who suffered from what was called 
hysteria at the time, and their complaints hadn’t been taken
seriously at all. From the women with depression 
he treated initially to World War I veterans with PTSD, Freud’s talking cure worked, and the visibility he gave his patients 
forced the medical establishment to acknowledge their psychological 
disorders were real. He certainly didn’t help all his patients. Freud was convinced
that our behavior is shaped by unconscious urges 
and repressed memories. He invented baseless unconscious 
or irrational drivers behind the behavior of trauma 
survivors— and caused real harm. How’s that? He misrepresented some of his most 
famous case studies, claiming his treatment had cured patients 
when in fact they had gotten worse. Later therapists influenced 
by his theories coaxed their patients into "recovering" supposedly repressed memories 
of childhood abuse that never happened. Lives and families were torn apart. You can’t blame Freud for later
misapplications of his work— that would be projecting. Plenty of his ideas were harmful 
without any misapplication. He viewed homosexuality 
as a developmental glitch. He coined the term penis envy— meaning women are haunted for life
by their lack of penises. Freud was a product of his era. Yes, some of the specifics were flawed, but he created a new space 
for future scientists to explore, investigate, and build upon. Modern therapy techniques
that millions of people rely on came out of the work he started 
with psychoanalysis. And today everyone knows 
there’s an unconscious— that idea was popularized Freud. Psychologists today only believe 
in a “cognitive unconscious,” the fact that you aren’t aware 
of everything going on at a given moment. Freud took this idea way too far, 
ascribing deep meaning to everything. He built his theories on scientific ideas
that were outdated even in his own time, not just by today’s standards— for example, he thought 
individual psychology is derived from the biological inheritance
of events in ancient history. And I mean ancient— 
like the Ice Age or the killing of Moses. Freud and his closest allies actually 
believed these prehistorical traumas had ongoing impacts on human psychology. He thought that the phase 
of cold indifference to sexuality during pubescence was literally 
an echo of the Ice Age. With fantastical beliefs like these,
how can we take him seriously? Any renowned thinker from centuries past has ideas that seem fantastical 
by today’s standards, but we can’t discount 
their influence on this basis. Freud was an innovator 
linking ideas across many fields. His concepts have become everyday terms that shape how we understand and talk 
about our own experiences. The Oedipus complex? Ego and id? 
Defense mechanisms? Death wishes? All Freud. But Freud didn’t present himself as a 
social theorist— he insisted that his work was scientific. Are you saying he… repressed
inconvenient facts? Freud’s theories were unfalsifiable. Wait, so you’re saying he was right? No, his ideas were framed so that 
there’s no way to empirically verify them. Freud didn’t even necessarily believe 
in the psychoanalysis he was peddling. He was pessimistic 
about the impact of therapy. What! I think I need to lie down! Many of Sigmund Freud’s ideas 
don’t hold up to modern science, and his clinical practices don’t meet 
today’s ethical standards. At the same time, he sparked 
a revolution in psychology and society, and created a vocabulary 
for discussing emotion. Freud made his share of mistakes. But is a thinker responsible 
for how subsequent generations put their ideas to use? Do they deserve the blame, 
credit, or redemption when we put history on trial?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Critics complain that some of Freud’s case studies are:
Options: A. Too long, B. Unscientific, C. Fraudulent, D. b & c, E. None of the above, F. Pornographic
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
Working in Vienna at the turn 
of the 20th century, he began his career as a neurologist before pioneering the discipline 
of psychoanalysis. He proposed that people are motivated 
by unconscious desires and repressed memories, and their problems can be addressed by making those motivations conscious 
through talk therapy. His influence towers above that of all 
other psychologists in the public eye. But was Sigmund Freud 
right about human nature? And were his methods scientific? Order, order. 
Today on the stand we have… Dad? Ahem, no, your honor. This is Doctor Sigmund Freud, one of the most innovative thinkers
in the history of psychology. An egomaniac who propagated 
pseudoscientific theories. Well, which is it? He tackled issues medicine 
refused to address. Freud’s private practice treated women who suffered from what was called 
hysteria at the time, and their complaints hadn’t been taken
seriously at all. From the women with depression 
he treated initially to World War I veterans with PTSD, Freud’s talking cure worked, and the visibility he gave his patients 
forced the medical establishment to acknowledge their psychological 
disorders were real. He certainly didn’t help all his patients. Freud was convinced
that our behavior is shaped by unconscious urges 
and repressed memories. He invented baseless unconscious 
or irrational drivers behind the behavior of trauma 
survivors— and caused real harm. How’s that? He misrepresented some of his most 
famous case studies, claiming his treatment had cured patients 
when in fact they had gotten worse. Later therapists influenced 
by his theories coaxed their patients into "recovering" supposedly repressed memories 
of childhood abuse that never happened. Lives and families were torn apart. You can’t blame Freud for later
misapplications of his work— that would be projecting. Plenty of his ideas were harmful 
without any misapplication. He viewed homosexuality 
as a developmental glitch. He coined the term penis envy— meaning women are haunted for life
by their lack of penises. Freud was a product of his era. Yes, some of the specifics were flawed, but he created a new space 
for future scientists to explore, investigate, and build upon. Modern therapy techniques
that millions of people rely on came out of the work he started 
with psychoanalysis. And today everyone knows 
there’s an unconscious— that idea was popularized Freud. Psychologists today only believe 
in a “cognitive unconscious,” the fact that you aren’t aware 
of everything going on at a given moment. Freud took this idea way too far, 
ascribing deep meaning to everything. He built his theories on scientific ideas
that were outdated even in his own time, not just by today’s standards— for example, he thought 
individual psychology is derived from the biological inheritance
of events in ancient history. And I mean ancient— 
like the Ice Age or the killing of Moses. Freud and his closest allies actually 
believed these prehistorical traumas had ongoing impacts on human psychology. He thought that the phase 
of cold indifference to sexuality during pubescence was literally 
an echo of the Ice Age. With fantastical beliefs like these,
how can we take him seriously? Any renowned thinker from centuries past has ideas that seem fantastical 
by today’s standards, but we can’t discount

a revolution in psychology and society, and created a vocabulary 
for discussing emotion. Freud made his share of mistakes. But is a thinker responsible 
for how subsequent generations put their ideas to use? Do they deserve the blame, 
credit, or redemption when we put history on trial?
